title: The Cup of Wrath
subtitle: When the Innocent drinks the judgment that was ours

key_verse.text: At three in the afternoon Jesus cried out in a loud voice, 'Eloi, Eloi, lema sabachthani?' (which means 'My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?').

cards.title: The Cup: The Symbol of Divine Judgment
cards.subtitle: Why Jesus feared it so much
cards.content:
In Gethsemane, Jesus prays: 'Abba, Father... take THIS CUP from me' (Mark 14:36).

‚ùì THE QUESTION:

Why does Jesus, who healed lepers and raised the dead, have such dread of a 'cup'?

He didn't fear physical death. Many martyrs died singing.

üç∑ THE CUP IN THE OLD TESTAMENT:

In prophetic language, 'the cup' represents GOD'S WRATH against sin:

üìñ ISAIAH 51:17:
'Awake, awake... you who have drunk from the hand of the LORD the CUP OF HIS WRATH... drained it to its dregs.'

üìñ PSALM 75:8:
'In the hand of the LORD is a CUP... all the wicked of the earth will DRAIN it down to its very dregs.'

üìñ JEREMIAH 25:15:
'Take from my hand this CUP filled with THE WINE OF MY WRATH and make all the nations to whom I send you drink it.'

‚öñÔ∏è WHAT THE CUP REPRESENTS:

‚Ä¢ The JUDGMENT the Law demanded on transgressors
‚Ä¢ The SEPARATION from God that sin produces
‚Ä¢ Holy WRATH against all evil
‚Ä¢ The ETERNAL punishment we deserved

üíî THE HORROR OF GETHSEMANE:

Jesus, the only innocent one, realizes that to be the Mediator of the New Covenant, He must DRINK the cup that was meant for us.

It's not just dying. It's absorbing the COMPLETE JUDGMENT.

üéØ THE DIFFERENCE:

‚Ä¢ Martyrs die for their faith
‚Ä¢ Jesus dies UNDER THE WRATH of God

He doesn't die as a victim; He dies as a SUBSTITUTE.
cards.revelation_key: The 'cup' was not a poetic symbol. It was the literal judgment of God against all human sin concentrated in one moment, upon one person.

cards.title: Enkataleip≈ç: The Cry of Abandonment
cards.subtitle: The most heart-wrenching word from Calvary
cards.content:
Mark 15:34 - 'Eloi, Eloi, lema sabachthani?' - My God, my God, why have You FORSAKEN me?

üìñ JESUS QUOTES PSALM 22:1:

He wasn't improvising. He was quoting the first verse of David's prophetic Psalm about the suffering Messiah.

For a Jew, quoting the first verse invoked the ENTIRE psalm.

üíî THE KEY WORD: ENKATALEIP≈å (Strong G1459)

‚Ä¢ EN = In/within
‚Ä¢ KATA = Down/completely
‚Ä¢ LEIP≈å = To leave/abandon

Meaning: To ABANDON in a situation of need, to leave behind in a dark place, to forsake totally.

It's the same word used when someone abandons a sinking ship.

ü§î THE THEOLOGICAL QUESTION:

Was there a REAL separation in the Trinity?

Since God is One, it's impossible for the Father and Son to 'divorce.'

BUT... something ontologically unique occurred:

üî• THE WEIGHT OF SIN:

2 Corinthians 5:21 - 'God made him who had no sin to BE sin for us.'

It doesn't say Jesus 'sinned,' but that His legal person was IDENTIFIED with the total mass of human sin.

üëÅÔ∏è THE REACTION OF HOLINESS:

Habakkuk 1:13 - God is 'too pure to LOOK on evil.'

When Jesus 'became sin,' He experienced for the first time in eternity the INTERRUPTION of sensible communion with the Father.

‚ò†Ô∏è WHAT THIS MEANS:

The 'separation' is, in essence, what Hell IS.

Hell = Total absence of God's benevolent presence.

For us to never be separated from God, the Son had to be separated IN OUR PLACE.

greek_words.meaning: To abandon completely, to forsake in need
greek_words.revelation: Jesus experienced the absolute abandonment of God - hell itself - so you would never have to experience it.
Christ became a CURSE so we could receive the BLESSING (eulogia). Total exchange.
'Without holiness no one will see the Lord' (Hebrews 12:14). Jesus was made 'un-holy' before the law so we could receive His holiness.

cards.revelation_key: Jesus' fear in Gethsemane wasn't of the nails. It was of the Father's silence. He, who lived in eternal love, knew He would become the target of divine justice.

cards.title: Psalm 22: The Prophecy from 1000 Years Before
cards.subtitle: Exact details of the crucifixion David never saw
cards.content:
Psalm 22, written by David ~1000 years before Christ, describes details of crucifixion that David never experienced.

Crucifixion didn't even exist as an execution method in David's time.

üìä PROPHETIC COMPARISON:

üó£Ô∏è PSALM 22:7-8:
'All who see me mock me; they hurl insults, shaking their heads. He trusts in the LORD, let the LORD rescue him.'

‚úÖ MARK 15:29-32:
'Those who passed by hurled insults at him, shaking their heads... He saved others, but he can't save himself!'

üî® PSALM 22:16:
'They PIERCED my hands and my feet.'

The Hebrew word 'kaaru' = to pierce, to bore through.

‚úÖ MARK 15:24:
'When they had CRUCIFIED him...'

üëï PSALM 22:18:
'They divide my CLOTHES among them and cast LOTS for my garment.'

‚úÖ MARK 15:24:
'Dividing up his clothes, they cast LOTS to see what each would get.'

üíÄ PSALM 22:15:
'My mouth is dried up like a potsherd, and my tongue sticks to the roof of my mouth; you lay me in the dust of death.'

‚úÖ JOHN 19:28:
'I am THIRSTY.'

üéØ THE SUPERNATURAL PRECISION:

These specific details of an execution method that didn't exist in his era prove:
‚Ä¢ Divine inspiration of the Psalm
‚Ä¢ Literal fulfillment in Christ
‚Ä¢ Eternal plan of redemption

üåÖ THE END OF PSALM 22:

What few notice: the Psalm ends with VICTORY.

Psalm 22:31 in Hebrew ends with 'ASAH' = 'He has done it' / 'It is finished.'

It's exactly what Jesus cried: 'TETELESTAI' (It is finished).

scripture_connections.text: My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?
But he was pierced for our transgressions, he was crushed for our iniquities
God made him who had no sin to be sin for us, so that in him we might become the righteousness of God
Christ redeemed us from the curse of the law by becoming a curse for us

cards.revelation_key: Psalm 22 is the prophetic script that Jesus fulfilled to the letter. It began with abandonment but ended with accomplished victory.

cards.title: Made Sin and Curse
cards.subtitle: The most glorious exchange in history
cards.content:
To understand the 'cup,' we must understand the legal EXCHANGE that occurred on the cross.

üîÑ THE GREAT EXCHANGE:

2 CORINTHIANS 5:21:
'God made him who had NO SIN to BE SIN for us, so that in him we might become the RIGHTEOUSNESS OF GOD.'

GALATIANS 3:13:
'Christ redeemed us from the CURSE of the law by becoming a CURSE for us.'

üìã WHAT JESUS TOOK:

‚úì Our SIN (2 Cor 5:21)
‚úì Our CURSE (Gal 3:13)
‚úì Our DEATH (Rom 6:23)
‚úì Our SEPARATION from God
‚úì Our CONDEMNATION (Rom 8:1)

üéÅ WHAT WE RECEIVED:

‚úì His RIGHTEOUSNESS (2 Cor 5:21)
‚úì His BLESSING (Gal 3:14)
‚úì His LIFE (Rom 6:23)
‚úì His COMMUNION with the Father
‚úì His ETERNAL acquittal

‚öñÔ∏è HEBREWS 12:14:

'Without HOLINESS (hagiasmos) no one will see the Lord.'

The problem:
‚Ä¢ All have sinned (Rom 3:23)
‚Ä¢ No one is holy by nature
‚Ä¢ God's holiness CONSUMES sin

üí° THE SOLUTION:

Jesus was intrinsically HOLY (hagios).

But on the cross there was a LEGAL IMPUTATION:
‚Ä¢ The Father saw in the Son all our wickedness
‚Ä¢ Jesus was treated as 'UN-HOLY' temporarily
‚Ä¢ That's why the Father had to turn His face away

‚ú® THE RESULT TODAY:

When God looks at you, He does NOT see your failures.
He sees Christ's HOLINESS covering you.

You're not a forgiven sinner.
You're a SAINT with a forgiven past.
cards.identity_statement: Jesus lost sight of the Father so you would never lose it. He was made 'un-holy' before the law so you could fulfill the requirement: 'Without holiness no one will see the Lord.'
cards.revelation_key: It wasn't just that Jesus died for you. It was that He became EVERYTHING you were (sin, curse, death) so you could be EVERYTHING He is (righteous, blessed, alive).

discovery_questions.question: Do you understand that what Jesus feared in Gethsemane wasn't physical pain, but separation from the Father? How does this change your view of the cross?
If 'separation from God' is hell, and Jesus experienced it for you, how valuable are you to God? How does this combat your feelings of insignificance?
Do you live as a 'forgiven sinner' struggling to be accepted, or as a 'saint with a forgiven past' who has already been accepted? What is your identity?
When you think of the cross, do you only think of 'forgiveness of sins,' or do you understand the COMPLETE exchange - that He took ALL that was yours to give you ALL that was His?

prayer.title: Prayer of the Exchange
prayer.content: Lord Jesus, today I understand more deeply what You suffered on the cross. It wasn't just physical pain. It was the total abandonment of the Father. You drank the ENTIRE cup of wrath that was meant for me. You became SIN so I could be made RIGHTEOUSNESS. You became a CURSE so I could receive BLESSING. You experienced the HELL of separation so I would never have to experience it. Forgive my lack of appreciation for Your sacrifice. Help me to live today not as someone trying to 'earn' Your love, but as someone for whom You already paid the highest price. You drank my cup. Now I can drink from Your joy. In Jesus' name, Amen.
